thread.section_title: Business & Finance News - Wall Street Journal
thread.title: Warehousing Nears Balance, China’s Vietnam Connection, Bananas’ Short Supply

author: Paul Page
title: Warehousing Nears Balance, China’s Vietnam Connection, Bananas’ Short Supply
text:
0 COMMENTS Sign up: With one click, get this newsletter delivered to your inbox .
Warehouse developers appear to be catching up to e-commerce-fueled demand. The supply of new industrial real estate in the U.S. edged closer to total demand in first quarter, according to brokerage CBRE Group Inc. CBRE -1.32% WSJ Logistics Report’s Erica E. Phillips writes that developers completed more than 216 million square feet of new warehouse space in the quarter, a growth pace that brings the overall market closer to equilibrium . There hasn’t been much sign of prices leveling off from rapid growth trends, however, although the real estate group noted sharp increases in availability in some big markets from the fourth quarter to the first, including Atlanta and Dallas. CBRE sees an overall “strong supply pipeline” of warehouses in development. But the group expects rapid economic growth and the continued big expansion in e-commerce to absorb that capacity and more for the rest of the year.
The highly contentious steel supply chain between China and the U.S. increasingly runs through Vietnam. On the coast near Ho Chi Minh City, dozens of factories have been following a simple and lucrative business model by importing import steel from China, galvanizing it and then exporting it —often to the U.S. The WSJ’s Chuin-Wei Yap, Scott Patterson and Bob Tita report the companies have used the blueprint to make Vietnam one of the fastest-growing suppliers of steel to the U.S. That also places the country in the line of fire in a simmering U.S.-China trade war, with U.S. officials arguing Chinese suppliers are transshipping goods to dump their steel at prices that undercut American producers. Vietnam and other Southeast Asian nations may get hit by sanctions aimed at China, although one analyst warns “you’re going to get into a quagmire” if that happens.
Bananas have been on a supply chain roller-coaster this year, but U.S. consumers aren’t seeing that at local supermarkets. Retailers have been keeping prices for the fruit steady at stores, even as wholesale prices have been going, well, bananas on a pullback in global supplies , highlighting the pricing complications in perishables’ supply chains. The WSJ’s Lucy Craymer writes wholesale banana prices hit a record high during the first quarter, soaring 15.5% in the first two months of the year. Production has been limited by events including floods and mudslides in Costa Rica and Guatemala and a plantation workers’ strike in Honduras. Store owners are loath to raise prices to consumers, however, because they believe the fruit helps drive foot traffic. And the slimmer supplies push retailers to get more of their inventory on shelves faster so they don’t have to eat the losses.
SUPPLY CHAIN STRATEGIES Photo: Bloomberg News New technology may start creating different patterns for inventories in apparel supply chains. Some factories in southern China are working with software that’s aimed at making the very fastest of fast fashion , offering custom-made clothing and shoes. The WSJ’s Natasha Khan reports the business model is being called “click, buy and make,” and aims to sharply curtail the time from purchase to shipping in a field that’s both notoriously inefficient and extremely sensitive to rapidly-changing tastes. Spencer Fung, who runs Hong Kong’s Li & Fung Ltd. , one of the largest supply-chain managers in the global garment industry, said new technologies could ultimately mean that more companies would be able to place small orders and avoid being stuck with extra inventory. Production costs remain a concern, but companies say advancements in automation will help them stitch together the leanest of lean supply chains.
QUOTABLE
‘ Just look at the average size of orders—it’s been going down for years. It went from hundreds of thousands to tens of thousands. And it will keep going down until it approaches a unit of one. ’
—Spencer Fung of supplier Li & Fung Ltd., on the impact of technology on apparel orders.
Number of the Day 17.1% Year-over-year change in container imports into California’s Port of Long Beach in the first quarter.
IN OTHER NEWS U.S. wholesale prices rose broadly in March . (WSJ)
Europe’s largest economies appear set for slower growth , according to the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development. (WSJ)
Russia’s currency fell to its lowest level against the dollar in around 16 months in the wake of new U.S. sanctions . (WSJ)
Aluminum futures soared after the London Metal Exchange suspended trading on metal from Russia’s United Co. Rusal . (WSJ)
Boeing Co. expanded aircraft deliveries in the first quarter while rival Airbus SE pulled back amid supplier turmoil . (WSJ)
Kroger Co. is hiring 11,000 workers as part of a three-year plan to overhaul existing supermarkets instead of building new ones. (WSJ)
Walmart Inc. set tougher delivery standards for its suppliers as of April 1 . (Arkansas Business)
Average logistics-manager compensation measured in a survey inched up just less than 1% last year . (Logistics Management)
Amazon.com Inc. is fighting calls for the retailer to register a Kentucky distribution center under federal food-safety regulations . (Food Safety News)
Volkswagen AG canceled most of its contracts with parts maker Prevent Group following a series of supply problems . (Automotive Logistics)
Chinese auto parts supplier Qingdao Doublestar will buy debt-laden South Korean manufacturer Kumho Tire. (Nikki Asian Review)
E-commerce fulfillment company Radial Corp. expanded operations at its Columbus, Ohio-area distribution center . (Columbus Dispatch)
Chinese solar panel maker Trina Solar won’t place a factory in the U.S. to get around new tariffs . (South China Morning Post)
Container shipping lines are adding more premium services as they seek to differentiate their operations . (Journal of Commerce)
CSX Corp. is selling 176 miles of track in Alabama and Georgia to HGS Railway Holdings Inc. for operation as short lines . (Progressive Railroading)
Airport services company Swissport withdrew its planned initial public offering on Switzerland’s stock exchange. (The Loadstar)
Toronto-based InstarAGF Asset Management Inc. acquired AMPORTS Inc., a Jacksonville, Fla.-based automotive port terminal operator . (American Shipper)
ABOUT US Paul Page is deputy editor of WSJ Logistics Report. Follow him at @PaulPage , and follow the WSJ Logistics Report team: @jensmithWSJ and @EEPhillips_WSJ . Follow the WSJ Logistics Report on Twitter at @WSJLogistics .
